skills.name: Write decimals with one decimal place
Read decimals with two decimal places
Write decimals with two decimal places
Read decimals with three or more decimal places
Recognise the place value of each digit in decimals

explanations.A: This would be five thousand, three hundred in words. To work out fifty-three hundredths as a decimal we need to do the calculation 53 divided by 100 (53/100). What would this be as a decimal?
explanations.B: 53 hundredths is the same as 53/100. 53 divided by 100 gives you 0.53 as a decimal.
explanations.C: This is 53 thousandths. 53 hundredths means 53 divided by 100 (53/100) what would that give you as a decimal?
explanations.D: This is 53 ten thousandths: 53/10000. We need to do the calculation 53 divided by 100 (53/100). What would this be as a decimal?

explanations.A: This is 19 thousandths. 19 hundredths means 19 divided by 100 (19/100) what would that give you as a decimal?
explanations.B: This is 19 ten thousandths: 19/10000. We need to do the calculation 19 divided by 100 (19/100). What would this be as a decimal?
explanations.C: This would be one thousand, nine hundred or 19 hundreds in words. To work out nineteen hundredths as a decimal we need to do the calculation 19 divided by 100 (19/100). What would this be as a decimal?
explanations.D: Nineteen hundredths is the same as 19/100. 19 divided by 100 gives you 0.19 as a decimal.

explanations.A: When we say "thirty five", we mean three tens and five ones. But we don't have any tens or ones in this number. We just need to say each digit separately and remember to include the decimal point.
explanations.B: We start with the 0 which we say as "zero" or "nought". We then say "point" for the decimal point. The digits 3 and 5 follow and we read each digit separately after the decimal point. Putting this together, we say "zero point three five."
explanations.C: When we say "thirty five", we mean three tens and five ones. But we don't have any tens or ones in this number. We just need to say each digit separately.
explanations.D: When reading the 0, we say "zero" or "nought" - this is different to the letter O. Remember to include the decimal point.

explanations.A: When we say "eighty four", we mean eight tens and four ones. But we don't have any tens or ones in this number. We just need to say each digit separately and remember to include the decimal point.
explanations.B: When reading the 0, we say "zero" or "nought" - this is different to the letter O. Remember to include the decimal point.
explanations.C: When we say "eighty four", we mean eight tens and four ones. But we don't have any tens or ones in this number. We just need to say each digit separately.
explanations.D: We start with the 0 which we say as "zero" or "nought". We then say "point" for the decimal point. The digits 8 and 4 follow and we read each digit separately after the decimal point. Putting this together, we say "zero point eight four."

explanations.A: You have just stated the digit. Consider the place value columns and what the 3 is worth in that column.
explanations.B: I think you have read the decimal point or the digit in the wrong place value.
explanations.C: The 3 is in the hundredths column so would be worth 3 hundredths - 0.03.
explanations.D: I think you have read the decimal point or the digit in the wrong place value.

explanations.A: The 6 is in the hundredths column so would be worth 6 hundredths - 0.06.
explanations.B: I think you have read the decimal point or the digit in the wrong place value.
explanations.C: You have just stated the digit. Consider the place value columns and what the 6 is worth in that column.
explanations.D: I think you have read the decimal point or the digit in the wrong place value.

explanations.A: To write two tenths (2/10) in decimal form, we write a 2 in the tenths place value column (the place after the decimal point). So, 0.2 = two tenths.
explanations.B: 20 is 2 tens. But we want 2 tenths. The tenths place value column is immediately after the decimal point.
explanations.C: 0.02 is 2 hundredths. But we want 2 tenths. The tenths place value column is immediately after the decimal point.
explanations.D: 2/10 is two tenths in fraction form. But we want two tenths in decimal form. The tenths place value column is immediately after the decimal point.

explanations.A: To write five tenths (5/10) in decimal form, we write a 5 in the tenths place value column (the place after the decimal point). So, 0.5 = five tenths.
explanations.B: 5/10 is five tenths in fraction form. But we want five tenths in decimal form. The tenths place value column is immediately after the decimal point.
explanations.C: 50 is 5 tens. But we want 5 tenths. The tenths place value column is immediately after the decimal point.
explanations.D: 0.05 is 5 hundredths. But we want 5 tenths. The tenths place value column is immediately after the decimal point.

explanations.A: Notice that "253" is written after a decimal point. So, this is not 253 wholes. What is the name of the place value for the final digit (the 3)? This will tell you if we have 253 tenths, hundredths or thousandths etc.
explanations.B: To write 0.253 in words, first write the number after the decimal point as a whole number: "two hundred and fifty-three". Then write the name of the place value of the final digit, which is "thousandths". Therefore, we have two hundred and fifty-three thousandths.
explanations.C: Not quite, what is the name of the place value for the final digit (the 3)? This will tell you if we have 253 tenths, hundredths or thousandths etc.
explanations.D: Not quite, what is the name of the place value for the final digit (the 3)? This will tell you if we have 253 tenths, hundredths or thousandths etc.

explanations.A: Not quite, what is the name of the place value for the final digit (the 4)? This will tell you if we have 374 tenths, hundredths or thousandths etc.
explanations.B: Not quite, what is the name of the place value for the final digit (the 4)? This will tell you if we have 374 tenths, hundredths or thousandths etc.
explanations.C: Notice that "374" is written after a decimal point. So, this is not 374 wholes. What is the name of the place value for the final digit (the 4)? This will tell you if we have 374 tenths, hundredths or thousandths etc.
explanations.D: To write 0.374 in words, first write the number after the decimal point as a whole number: "three hundred and seventy-four". Then write the name of the place value of the final digit, which is "thousandths". Therefore, we have three hundred and seventy-four thousandths.
